newsitem.title: UK: London precious metals weaker ahead of long weekend.
newsitem.headline: London precious metals weaker ahead of long weekend.

text.p: Gloomy sentiment prevailed in the precious metals markets on Friday, with sharply lower platinum and palladium prices setting the tone.
The market was reluctant to do more than clear the books ahead of a long holiday weekend in Britain and the United States, traders said.
Still, the downside was beckoning for the complex after the platinum group metals (PGMs) took a kicking on a weaker yen and news that long-delayed Russian supplies were imminent.
In the absence of consumer interest, gold also followed suit, fixed at an easier $341.65 per ounce.
It had previously been fixed at $342.75 on Thursday afternoon and closed in London at $342.50/$343.00.
Dealers said it could tick still lower by the end of the day although chart-wise support was expected to emerge at the $340.00 level.
"People don't want to do much at the end of the week. But the PGMs remain the market's focus and sentiment doesn't look great," a trader said.
Dealers were also closely watching to see whether Australian producers would sell gold after the central bank cut official cash rates.
A resulting fall in the value of the Australian dollar against the U.S. currency means Australian gold will get a higher return in Australian dollars.
But the centre of attention was still palladium, which tumbled to fix dramatically lower at $168.50 an ounce, compared to $174.50 on Thursday afternoon.
The drop in spot palladium in Europe followed a sell-off in yen-based futures in Tokyo in which all months expect for limitless May fell by their daily limit.
Aggressive selling by private investors was triggered by news this week that long-delayed talks between Russian suppliers and Japanese consumers are due to start next month, dealers in Tokyo said.
A rise in the U.S. dollar against the yen was also discouraging Japanese importers.
Platinum was similarly easier, fixing at $387.00 an ounce versus $388.75 the previous afternoon. It subsequently eased further to around $385.00 in European trading.
Silver was easier at $4.66/$4.68, down two cents. It was seen following gold's lead, with support seen at $4.60.
